prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: To estimate the sensitivity requirements we used the single-dish detections of Heikkila et al. (1999). The key line we base our calculations on is the brightest PDR line, C2H. According to Heikkila et al. (1999), its peak brightness is 36 mK in a 44" beam towards 30 Dor (the fainter of the main GMCs). We expect that these dense gas species are more compact than CO. Conservatively, we estimate that emission uniformly covers a diameter of ~15" , close to the maximum spatial scale resolvable by ALMA. This implies that in a given 8" ALMA beam peak brightnesses will be 0.30 K. We would like to reach a depth such that this value corresponds to a 12 sigma detection in 0.5 km/s. According to Heikkila et al., c-C3H2 will be about half the peak of C2H so will is likely be detected towards the brighter cores. For the dense gas tracer CS Heikkila et al. finds it is 1.6 times brighter, so no additional time is required to detect it. The shock tracer brightnesses are less well known but the observed sensitivity will provide an acceptable limit if not detected. This means that our maps need to reach an RMS of 25 mK in an ALMA beam. The spectral lines are narrow (2-4 km/s) and limited to about an extent of 20 km/s so we will need the 58 MHz bandwidth with spectral resolution of ~0.5 km/s (the value we calculate or sensitivity for), which is possible given the correlator setup. Mosaics of ~30 pc (2') are required to cover the bulk of the GMC areas.
In order to keep the same absolute limits to all other locations, we adopt the identical setup towards all positions - see the technical justification for the 30Dor-10 science goal.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) is the nearest major galaxy to the Milky Way and is a perfect testbed for star formation studies on galactic scales. It contains the most intense star forming region in the Local Group, 30 Doradus, but also some quiet molecular regions, a ram pressure interaction zone, as well as a stellar bar to name but a few prominent features. In particular, a molecular ridge that spans about 2 degrees starting at 30 Doradus is a perfect location to study molecular gas properties over four orders of magnitude variations in radiation field. We propose to map regions along this molecular ridge, but also at other well-chosen positions in the LMC in molecular lines that trace photon-dissociated regions, shocks, and gas density. The cloud selection will allow us to measure molecular properties and the underlying physics as a function of a) cloud mass, b) radiation field, c) shock strength, and d) distance from the center of the LMC. This comprehensive survey will make up a portion of a student thesis with the goal of understanding how the radiative and mechanical feedback from massive stars affect star formation from the clump (few pc) scale to GMC scales and beyond.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00802.S - Dense Gas, Shocks and PDRs across the LMC - PI: Anderson
